useCaseType: Daily Life Support (Assistive Tech, Smart Home, IoT, or Public Services)
name: Privacy-Focused Daily Assistance
description: Olivia uses ALFRED to manage daily tasks with strict privacy controls and minimal notifications, preferring formal communication and limited data sharing to maintain her independence and comfort with technology.
scenario:
Olivia, a retired social worker who has always been wary of technology, keeps a cautious distance from ALFRED despite its promise to help her maintain independence. She insists on using the system strictly on her terms, activating voice commands only when she feels ready, often pressing the push-to-talk button deliberately to maintain control. The system’s usual proactive suggestions and notifications irritate her, so she configures ALFRED to minimize interruptions, rejecting nearly all unsolicited alerts—even those about health or activity reminders. Olivia’s need for privacy is paramount; she carefully blocks all app installations unless she explicitly requests them, firmly refusing any data sharing with family members or caregivers, fearing misuse or judgment.

Her stoic and formal tone shapes every interaction with ALFRED. When Olivia asks about her schedule or requests a reminder to drink water, she expects concise, professional responses without any casual chat or excessive explanation. The assistant’s usual friendly demeanor feels intrusive to her, so she disables detailed feature explanations, preferring to use ALFRED purely functionally. Despite the system’s capability for video check-ins, Olivia declines these, finding the idea invasive and preferring to manage check-ins offline, even if it means less immediate support. She rarely wears any wearable sensors because she mistrusts their data sharing, insisting that if she does, it must be under strict conditions preventing any third-party access.

This guarded approach sometimes frustrates ALFRED’s design assumptions, which aim to offer supportive, engaging care. Olivia’s reluctance to accept help or open communication channels creates tension between her desire for independence and the system’s proactive care model. Yet, ALFRED respects her boundaries, providing only the assistance she explicitly requests and strictly formalizing all communications to match her preferences. While this limits some of the system’s more dynamic benefits, it allows Olivia to maintain a sense of control and dignity, navigating her daily tasks without unwanted intrusion or perceived loss of privacy.
